subject: Switzerland-EU Relations: Trade and Free Movement of Persons
key_concepts: Free Movement of Persons Agreement (PFZ) and its evolution
Alternatives to bilateral status quo (deep FTA vs. EEA)
Dynamic vs. static legal adaptation in agreements
why: This document covers two core pillars of Swiss-EU relations (trade and free movement) which are central to understanding the bilateral approach. It details specific agreements, legal principles, and political tensions that are classic exam topics for advanced seminars on European integration and Swiss foreign policy. The material includes treaty articles, case law, and comparative analysis of institutional alternatives—all typical fodder for essay and analytical questions.
likely_exam_questions: Compare and contrast the 1972 Free Trade Agreement with the EU's single market model. What are the legal and economic limitations of the Swiss approach?
Trace the judicial evolution of the EU's free movement principle from an economic right to a citizenship right and back. Use key cases (e.g., Martinez Sala, Dano) in your analysis.
Analyze the political and legal safeguards available to Switzerland (PFZ) and an EEA member (Art. 112 EWR) to restrict free movement. How do they differ in theory and practice?

Evaluate the two main alternatives to Switzerland's current bilateral path: a 'deep' free trade agreement (UK model) and EEA membership (Norwegian model). Discuss the implications for sovereignty and market access.
Explain the significance of the 'Dano principle' and its political context. How did it change the application of the Free Movement of Persons Directive?
connections: Brexit and its impact on EU migration policy
difficulty_spikes: Distinguishing between the legal effects of static (FTA 1972) and dynamic (e.g., Zollabkommen 2011) adaptation clauses.
Understanding the nuanced shift in ECJ/CJEU jurisprudence from expansive (Martinez Sala) to restrictive (Dano) interpretations of social rights for non-economically active EU migrants.
Grasping the technical differences between a free trade area (FTA), a customs union, and a single market (EEA).
Applying the abstract criteria of EEA Article 112 ('serious economic, societal, or environmental difficulties') to potential real-world scenarios.
prerequisites: Basic knowledge of EU institutions and treaties (especially AEUV/TFEU).
Understanding of the fundamental principles of the EU Internal Market (four freedoms).
Familiarity with the historical context of Swiss-EU relations, specifically the 1992 EEA rejection.
General concepts of international public law and treaty types (FTA vs. supranational law).
summary: This seminar document analyzes the two central pillars of Switzerland's bilateral relationship with the EU: trade in goods and the free movement of persons. It details the complex web of sectoral agreements governing trade (from the 1972 FTA to technical barriers and public procurement) and contrasts this bilateral model with the EU's single market and EEA membership. Simultaneously, it provides an advanced overview of the EU's free movement principle, tracing its legal evolution from an economic worker right to a citizenship right and its subsequent political backlash, highlighting key ECJ cases and their relevance for Switzerland's own agreement.
